Problem:
Consider a system governed by the heat equation \\(u_t = ku_{xx}\\), where \\(u\\) is the temperature distribution along a rod, and \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We investigate the effects of an initial heat distribution function \\(h(x)\\) and a later heat source intervention represented by \\(s(x, t)\\).

Given the temperature distribution \\(u(x, T)\\), can we determine precisely which heat source interventions were used, if any, by knowing just the temperature at time \\(T\\)?
Explanation: Due to the diffusive nature of heat and potential overlapping effects of various heat source interventions, it is challenging to conclusively identify which specific interventions were applied solely based on the end temperature distribution. Multiple combinations of initial conditions and interventions could lead to similar distributions at a later time.
